00016 namespace GeographicLib {
00017 
00018   /**
00019    * \brief A geodesic line.
00020    *
00021    * GeodesicLine facilitates the determination of a series of points on a
00022    * single geodesic.  The starting point (\e lat1, \e lon1) and the azimuth \e
00023    * azi1 are specified in the constructor.  GeodesicLine.Position returns the
00024    * location of point 2 a distance \e s12 along the geodesic.  Alternatively
00025    * GeodesicLine.ArcPosition gives the position of point 2 an arc length \e
00026    * a12 along the geodesic.  An example of use of this class is:
00027    \code
00028    #include <iostream>
00029    #include <iomanip>
00030    #include <cmath>
00031    #include <GeographicLib/Geodesic.hpp>
00032    #include <GeographicLib/GeodesicLine.hpp>
00033 
00034    int main() {
00035      // Print waypoints between JFK and SIN at approximately
00036      // equal 100km intervals
00037      double
00038        lat1 = 40.640, lon1 = -73.779, // JFK
00039        lat2 =  1.359, lon2 = 177.486; // SIN
00040      const GeographicLib::Geodesic&
00041        g = GeographicLib::Geodesic::WGS84;
00042      double s12, azi1, azi2,
00043        a12 = g.Inverse(lat1, lon1, lat2, lon2, s12, azi1, azi2);
00044      double ds = 100e3;   // Nominal distance between points = 100 km
00045      int num = std::ceil(s12 / ds); // Number of intervals
00046      double da = a12/num;           // Arc length of each interval
00047      const GeographicLib::GeodesicLine l(g, lat1, lon1, azi1);
00048      std::cout << std::fixed << std::setprecision(3);
00049      for (int i = 0; i <= num; ++i) {
00050        double lat, lon;
00051        l.ArcPosition(i * da, lat, lon);
00052        std::cout << lat << " " << lon << "\n";
00053      }
00054    }
00055    \endcode
00056    * The default copy constructor and assignment operators work with this
00057    * class, so that, for example, the previous example could start
00058    \code
00059        GeographicLib::GeodesicLine l;
00060        l = g.Line(lat1, lon1, azi1);
00061    \endcode
00062    * Similarly, a vector can be used to hold GeodesicLine objects.
00063    *
00064    * The calculations are accurate to better than 15 nm.  See Sec. 9 of
00065    * <a href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1102.1215v1">arXiv:1102.1215v1</a> for details.
00066    *
00067    * The algorithms are described in
00068    * - C. F. F. Karney,
00069    *   <a href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1102.1215v1">Geodesics
00070    *   on an ellipsoid of revolution</a>,
00071    *   Feb. 2011;
00072    *   preprint
00073    *   <a href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1102.1215v1">arXiv:1102.1215v1</a>.
00074    * .
00075    * For more information on geodesics see \ref geodesic.
00076    **********************************************************************/
00077 
00078   class GEOGRAPHIC_EXPORT GeodesicLine {
00079   private:
00080     typedef Math::real real;
00081     friend class Geodesic;
00082     static const int nC1_ = Geodesic::nC1_;
00083     static const int nC1p_ = Geodesic::nC1p_;
00084     static const int nC2_ = Geodesic::nC2_;
00085     static const int nC3_ = Geodesic::nC3_;
00086     static const int nC4_ = Geodesic::nC4_;
00087 
00088     real _lat1, _lon1, _azi1;
00089     real _a, _r, _b, _c2, _f1, _salp0, _calp0, _k2,
00090       _salp1, _calp1, _ssig1, _csig1, _stau1, _ctau1, _somg1, _comg1,
00091       _A1m1, _A2m1, _A3c, _B11, _B21, _B31, _A4, _B41;
00092     // index zero elements of _C1a, _C1pa, _C2a, _C3a are unused
00093     real _C1a[nC1_ + 1], _C1pa[nC1p_ + 1], _C2a[nC2_ + 1], _C3a[nC3_],
00094       _C4a[nC4_];    // all the elements of _C4a are used
00095     bool _areap;
00096     unsigned _caps;
00097 
00098     enum captype {
00099       CAP_NONE = Geodesic::CAP_NONE,
00100       CAP_C1   = Geodesic::CAP_C1,
00101       CAP_C1p  = Geodesic::CAP_C1p,
00102       CAP_C2   = Geodesic::CAP_C2,
00103       CAP_C3   = Geodesic::CAP_C3,
00104       CAP_C4   = Geodesic::CAP_C4,
00105       CAP_ALL  = Geodesic::CAP_ALL,
00106       OUT_ALL  = Geodesic::OUT_ALL,
00107     };
00108   public:
00109 
00110     /**
00111      * Bit masks for what calculations to do.  These masks do double duty.
00112      * They signify to the GeodesicLine::GeodesicLine constructor and to
00113      * Geodesic::Line what capabilities should be included in the GeodesicLine
00114      * object.  They also specify which results to return in the general
00115      * routines Geodesic::GenDirect and Geodesic::GenInverse routines.  This is
00116      * merely a duplication of Geodesic::mask.
00117      **********************************************************************/
00118     enum mask {
00119       /**
00120        * No capabilities, no output.
00121        * @hideinitializer
00122        **********************************************************************/
00123       NONE          = Geodesic::NONE,
00124       /**
00125        * Calculate latitude \e lat2.  (It's not necessary to include this as a
00126        * capability to GeodesicLine because this is included by default.)
00127        * @hideinitializer
00128        **********************************************************************/
00129       LATITUDE      = Geodesic::LATITUDE,
00130       /**
00131        * Calculate longitude \e lon2.
00132        * @hideinitializer
00133        **********************************************************************/
00134       LONGITUDE     = Geodesic::LONGITUDE,
00135       /**
00136        * Calculate azimuths \e azi1 and \e azi2.  (It's not necessary to
00137        * include this as a capability to GeodesicLine because this is included
00138        * by default.)
00139        * @hideinitializer
00140        **********************************************************************/
00141       AZIMUTH       = Geodesic::AZIMUTH,
00142       /**
00143        * Calculate distance \e s12.
00144        * @hideinitializer
00145        **********************************************************************/
00146       DISTANCE      = Geodesic::DISTANCE,
00147       /**
00148        * Allow distance \e s12 to be used as input in the direct geodesic
00149        * problem.
00150        * @hideinitializer
00151        **********************************************************************/
00152       DISTANCE_IN   = Geodesic::DISTANCE_IN,
00153       /**
00154        * Calculate reduced length \e m12.
00155        * @hideinitializer
00156        **********************************************************************/
00157       REDUCEDLENGTH = Geodesic::REDUCEDLENGTH,
00158       /**
00159        * Calculate geodesic scales \e M12 and \e M21.
00160        * @hideinitializer
00161        **********************************************************************/
00162       GEODESICSCALE = Geodesic::GEODESICSCALE,
00163       /**
00164        * Calculate area \e S12.
00165        * @hideinitializer
00166        **********************************************************************/
00167       AREA          = Geodesic::AREA,
00168       /**
00169        * All capabilities.  Calculate everything.
00170        * @hideinitializer
00171        **********************************************************************/
00172       ALL           = Geodesic::ALL,
00173     };
00174 
00175     /** \name Constructors
00176      **********************************************************************/
00177     ///@{
00178 
00179     /**
00180      * Constructor for a geodesic line staring at latitude \e lat1, longitude
00181      * \e lon1, and aziumuth \e azi1 (all in degrees).
00182      *
00183      * @param[in] g A Geodesic object used to compute the necessary information
00184      *   about the GeodesicLine.
00185      *
00186      * @param[in] lat1 latitude of point 1 (degrees).
00187      * @param[in] lon1 longitude of point 1 (degrees).
00188      * @param[in] azi1 azimuth at point 1 (degrees).
00189      * @param[in] caps bitor'ed combination of GeodesicLine::mask values
00190      *   specifying the capabilities the GeodesicLine object should possess,
00191      *   i.e., which quantities can be returned in calls to
00192      *   GeodesicLib::Position.
00193      *
00194      * The GeodesicLine::mask values are
00195      * - \e caps |= GeodesicLine::LATITUDE for the latitude \e lat2; this is
00196      *   added automatically
00197      * - \e caps |= GeodesicLine::LONGITUDE for the latitude \e lon2
00198      * - \e caps |= GeodesicLine::AZIMUTH for the latitude \e azi2; this is
00199      *   added automatically
00200      * - \e caps |= GeodesicLine::DISTANCE for the distance \e s12
00201      * - \e caps |= GeodesicLine::REDUCEDLENGTH for the reduced length \e m12
00202      * - \e caps |= GeodesicLine::GEODESICSCALE for the geodesic scales \e M12
00203      *   and \e M21
00204      * - \e caps |= GeodesicLine::AREA for the area \e S12
00205      * - \e caps |= GeodesicLine::DISTANCE_IN permits the length of the
00206      *   geodesic to be given in terms of \e s12; without this capability the
00207      *   length can only be specified in terms of arc length.
00208      * .
00209      * The default value of \e caps is GeodesicLine::ALL which turns on all the
00210      * capabilities.
00211      *
00212      * If the point is at a pole, the azimuth is defined by keeping the \e lon1
00213      * fixed and writing \e lat1 = 90 - \e eps or -90 + \e eps and taking the
00214      * limit \e eps -> 0 from above.
00215      **********************************************************************/
00216     GeodesicLine(const Geodesic& g, real lat1, real lon1, real azi1,
00217                  unsigned caps = ALL)
00218       throw();
00219 
00220     /**
00221      * A default constructor.  If GeodesicLine::Position is called on the
00222      * resulting object, it returns immediately (without doing any
00223      * calculations).  The object can be set with a call to Geodesic::Line.
00224      * Use Init() to test whether object is still in this uninitialized state.
00225      **********************************************************************/
00226     GeodesicLine() throw() : _caps(0U) {};
00227     ///@}
00228 
00229     /** \name Position in terms of distance
00230      **********************************************************************/
00231     ///@{
00232 
00233     /**
00234      * Compute the position of point 2 which is a distance \e s12 (meters)
00235      * from point 1.
00236      *
00237      * @param[in] s12 distance between point 1 and point 2 (meters); it can be
00238      *   signed.
00239      * @param[out] lat2 latitude of point 2 (degrees).
00240      * @param[out] lon2 longitude of point 2 (degrees); requires that the
00241      *   GeodesicLine object was constructed with \e caps |=
00242      *   GeodesicLine::LONGITUDE.
00243      * @param[out] azi2 (forward) azimuth at point 2 (degrees).
00244      * @param[out] m12 reduced length of geodesic (meters); requires that the
00245      *   GeodesicLine object was constructed with \e caps |=
00246      *   GeodesicLine::REDUCEDLENGTH.
00247      * @param[out] M12 geodesic scale of point 2 relative to point 1
00248      *   (dimensionless); requires that the GeodesicLine object was constructed
00249      *   with \e caps |= GeodesicLine::GEODESICSCALE.
00250      * @param[out] M21 geodesic scale of point 1 relative to point 2
00251      *   (dimensionless); requires that the GeodesicLine object was constructed
00252      *   with \e caps |= GeodesicLine::GEODESICSCALE.
00253      * @param[out] S12 area under the geodesic (meters<sup>2</sup>); requires
00254      *   that the GeodesicLine object was constructed with \e caps |=
00255      *   GeodesicLine::AREA.
00256      * @return \e a12 arc length of between point 1 and point 2 (degrees).
00257      *
00258      * The GeodesicLine object \e must have been constructed with \e caps |=
00259      * GeodesicLine::DISTANCE_IN; otherwise Math::NaN() is returned and no
00260      * parameters are set.  Requesting a value which the GeodesicLine object is
00261      * not capable of computing is not an error; the corresponding argument
00262      * will not be altered.
00263      *
00264      * The following functions are overloaded versions of
00265      * GeodesicLine::Position which omit some of the output parameters.  Note,
00266      * however, that the arc length is always computed and returned as the
00267      * function value.
00268      **********************************************************************/
00269     Math::real Position(real s12,
00270                         real& lat2, real& lon2, real& azi2,
00271                         real& m12, real& M12, real& M21,
00272                         real& S12) const throw() {
00273       real t;
00274       return GenPosition(false, s12,
00275                          LATITUDE | LONGITUDE | AZIMUTH |
00276                          REDUCEDLENGTH | GEODESICSCALE | AREA,
00277                          lat2, lon2, azi2, t, m12, M12, M21, S12);
00278     }
00279 
00280     /**
00281      * See the documentation for GeodesicLine::Position.
00282      **********************************************************************/
00283     Math::real Position(real s12, real& lat2, real& lon2) const throw() {
00284       real t;
00285       return GenPosition(false, s12,
00286                          LATITUDE | LONGITUDE,
00287                          lat2, lon2, t, t, t, t, t, t);
00288     }
00289 
00290     /**
00291      * See the documentation for GeodesicLine::Position.
00292      **********************************************************************/
00293     Math::real Position(real s12, real& lat2, real& lon2,
00294                         real& azi2) const throw() {
00295       real t;
00296       return GenPosition(false, s12,
00297                          LATITUDE | LONGITUDE | AZIMUTH,
00298                          lat2, lon2, azi2, t, t, t, t, t);
00299     }
00300 
00301     /**
00302      * See the documentation for GeodesicLine::Position.
00303      **********************************************************************/
00304     Math::real Position(real s12, real& lat2, real& lon2,
00305                         real& azi2, real& m12) const throw() {
00306       real t;
00307       return GenPosition(false, s12,
00308                          LATITUDE | LONGITUDE |
00309                          AZIMUTH | REDUCEDLENGTH,
00310                          lat2, lon2, azi2, t, m12, t, t, t);
00311     }
00312 
00313     /**

00316     Math::real Position(real s12, real& lat2, real& lon2,
00317                         real& azi2, real& M12, real& M21)
00318       const throw() {
00319       real t;

00321                          LATITUDE | LONGITUDE |

00323                          lat2, lon2, azi2, t, t, M12, M21, t);

00326     /**
00327      * See the documentation for GeodesicLine::Position.

00330                         real& lat2, real& lon2, real& azi2,
00331                         real& m12, real& M12, real& M21)
00332       const throw() {
00333       real t;

00342     /** \name Position in terms of arc length
00343      **********************************************************************/
00344     ///@{
00345 
00346     /**
00347      * Compute the position of point 2 which is an arc length \e a12 (degrees)
00348      * from point 1.
00349      *
00350      * @param[in] a12 arc length between point 1 and point 2 (degrees); it can
00351      *   be signed.
00352      * @param[out] lat2 latitude of point 2 (degrees).
00353      * @param[out] lon2 longitude of point 2 (degrees); requires that the
00354      *   GeodesicLine object was constructed with \e caps |=
00355      *   GeodesicLine::LONGITUDE.
00356      * @param[out] azi2 (forward) azimuth at point 2 (degrees).
00357      * @param[out] s12 distance between point 1 and point 2 (meters); requires
00358      *   that the GeodesicLine object was constructed with \e caps |=
00359      *   GeodesicLine::DISTANCE.
00360      * @param[out] m12 reduced length of geodesic (meters); requires that the
00361      *   GeodesicLine object was constructed with \e caps |=
00362      *   GeodesicLine::REDUCEDLENGTH.
00363      * @param[out] M12 geodesic scale of point 2 relative to point 1
00364      *   (dimensionless); requires that the GeodesicLine object was constructed
00365      *   with \e caps |= GeodesicLine::GEODESICSCALE.
00366      * @param[out] M21 geodesic scale of point 1 relative to point 2
00367      *   (dimensionless); requires that the GeodesicLine object was constructed
00368      *   with \e caps |= GeodesicLine::GEODESICSCALE.
00369      * @param[out] S12 area under the geodesic (meters<sup>2</sup>); requires
00370      *   that the GeodesicLine object was constructed with \e caps |=
00371      *   GeodesicLine::AREA.
00372      *
00373      * Requesting a value which the GeodesicLine object is not capable of
00374      * computing is not an error; the corresponding argument will not be
00375      * altered.
00376      *
00377      * The following functions are overloaded versions of
00378      * GeodesicLine::ArcPosition which omit some of the output parameters.
00379      **********************************************************************/
00380     void ArcPosition(real a12, real& lat2, real& lon2, real& azi2,
00381                      real& s12, real& m12, real& M12, real& M21,
00382                      real& S12) const throw() {
00383       GenPosition(true, a12,
00384                   LATITUDE | LONGITUDE | AZIMUTH | DISTANCE |
00385                   REDUCEDLENGTH | GEODESICSCALE | AREA,
00386                   lat2, lon2, azi2, s12, m12, M12, M21, S12);
00387     }
00388 
00389     /**
00390      * See the documentation for GeodesicLine::ArcPosition.
00391      **********************************************************************/
00392     void ArcPosition(real a12, real& lat2, real& lon2)
00393       const throw() {
00394       real t;
00395       GenPosition(true, a12,
00396                   LATITUDE | LONGITUDE,
00397                   lat2, lon2, t, t, t, t, t, t);
00398     }

00460     ///@}
00461 
00462     /** \name The general position function.
00463      **********************************************************************/
00464     ///@{
00465 
00466     /**
00467      * The general position function.  GeodesicLine::Position and
00468      * GeodesicLine::ArcPosition are defined in terms of this function.
00469      *
00470      * @param[in] arcmode boolean flag determining the meaning of the second
00471      *   parameter; if arcmode is false, then the GeodesicLine object must have
00472      *   been constructed with \e caps |= GeodesicLine::DISTANCE_IN.
00473      * @param[in] s12_a12 if \e arcmode is false, this is the distance between
00474      *   point 1 and point 2 (meters); otherwise it is the arc length between
00475      *   point 1 and point 2 (degrees); it can be signed.
00476      * @param[in] outmask a bitor'ed combination of GeodesicLine::mask values
00477      *   specifying which of the following parameters should be set.
00478      * @param[out] lat2 latitude of point 2 (degrees).
00479      * @param[out] lon2 longitude of point 2 (degrees); requires that the
00480      *   GeodesicLine object was constructed with \e caps |=
00481      *   GeodesicLine::LONGITUDE.
00482      * @param[out] azi2 (forward) azimuth at point 2 (degrees).
00483      * @param[out] s12 distance between point 1 and point 2 (meters); requires
00484      *   that the GeodesicLine object was constructed with \e caps |=
00485      *   GeodesicLine::DISTANCE.
00486      * @param[out] m12 reduced length of geodesic (meters); requires that the
00487      *   GeodesicLine object was constructed with \e caps |=
00488      *   GeodesicLine::REDUCEDLENGTH.
00489      * @param[out] M12 geodesic scale of point 2 relative to point 1
00490      *   (dimensionless); requires that the GeodesicLine object was constructed
00491      *   with \e caps |= GeodesicLine::GEODESICSCALE.
00492      * @param[out] M21 geodesic scale of point 1 relative to point 2
00493      *   (dimensionless); requires that the GeodesicLine object was constructed
00494      *   with \e caps |= GeodesicLine::GEODESICSCALE.
00495      * @param[out] S12 area under the geodesic (meters<sup>2</sup>); requires
00496      *   that the GeodesicLine object was constructed with \e caps |=
00497      *   GeodesicLine::AREA.
00498      * @return \e a12 arc length of between point 1 and point 2 (degrees).
00499      *
00500      * The GeodesicLine::mask values possible for \e outmask are
00501      * - \e outmask |= GeodesicLine::LATITUDE for the latitude \e lat2.
00502      * - \e outmask |= GeodesicLine::LONGITUDE for the latitude \e lon2.
00503      * - \e outmask |= GeodesicLine::AZIMUTH for the latitude \e azi2.
00504      * - \e outmask |= GeodesicLine::DISTANCE for the distance \e s12.
00505      * - \e outmask |= GeodesicLine::REDUCEDLENGTH for the reduced length \e
00506      *   m12.
00507      * - \e outmask |= GeodesicLine::GEODESICSCALE for the geodesic scales \e
00508      *   M12 and \e M21.
00509      * - \e outmask |= GeodesicLine::AREA for the area \e S12.
00510      * .
00511      * Requesting a value which the GeodesicLine object is not capable of
00512      * computing is not an error; the corresponding argument will not be
00513      * altered.  Note, however, that the arc length is always computed and
00514      * returned as the function value.
00515      **********************************************************************/
00516     Math::real GenPosition(bool arcmode, real s12_a12, unsigned outmask,
00517                            real& lat2, real& lon2, real& azi2,
00518                            real& s12, real& m12, real& M12, real& M21,
00519                            real& S12) const throw();
00520 
00521     ///@}
00522 
00523     /** \name Inspector functions
00524      **********************************************************************/
00525     ///@{
00526 
00527     /**
00528      * @return true if the object has been initialized.
00529      **********************************************************************/
00530     bool Init() const throw() { return _caps != 0U; }
00531 
00532     /**
00533      * @return \e lat1 the latitude of point 1 (degrees).
00534      **********************************************************************/
00535     Math::real Latitude() const throw() { return Init() ? _lat1 : 0; }
00536 
00537     /**
00538      * @return \e lon1 the longitude of point 1 (degrees).
00539      **********************************************************************/
00540     Math::real Longitude() const throw() { return Init() ? _lon1 : 0; }
00541 
00542     /**
00543      * @return \e azi1 the azimuth (degrees) of the geodesic line at point 1.
00544      **********************************************************************/
00545     Math::real Azimuth() const throw() { return Init() ? _azi1 : 0; }
00546 
00547     /**
00548      * @return \e azi0 the azimuth (degrees) of the geodesic line as it crosses
00549      * the equator in a northward direction.
00550      **********************************************************************/
00551     Math::real EquatorialAzimuth() const throw() {
00552       return Init() ? atan2(_salp0, _calp0) / Math::degree<real>() : 0;
00553     }
00554 
00555     /**
00556      * @return \e a1 the arc length (degrees) between the northward equatorial
00557      * crossing and point 1.
00558      **********************************************************************/
00559     Math::real EquatorialArc() const throw() {
00560       return Init() ? atan2(_ssig1, _csig1) / Math::degree<real>() : 0;
00561     }
00562 
00563     /**
00564      * @return \e a the equatorial radius of the ellipsoid (meters).  This is
00565      *   the value inherited from the Geodesic object used in the constructor.
00566      **********************************************************************/
00567     Math::real MajorRadius() const throw() { return Init() ? _a : 0; }
00568 
00569     /**
00570      * @return \e r the inverse flattening of the ellipsoid.  This is the
00571      *   value inherited from the Geodesic object used in the constructor.  A
00572      *   value of 0 is returned for a sphere (infinite inverse flattening).
00573      **********************************************************************/
00574     Math::real InverseFlattening() const throw() { return Init() ? _r : 0; }
00575 
00576     /**
00577      * @return \e caps the computational capabilities that this object was
00578      *   constructed with.  LATITUDE and AZIMUTH are always included.
00579      **********************************************************************/
00580     unsigned Capabilities() const throw() { return _caps; }
00581 
00582     /**
00583      * @param[in] testcaps a set of bitor'ed GeodesicLine::mask values.
00584      * @return true if the GeodesicLine object has all these capabilities.
00585      **********************************************************************/
00586     bool Capabilities(unsigned testcaps) const throw() {
00587       testcaps &= OUT_ALL;
00588       return (_caps & testcaps) == testcaps;
00589     }
00590     ///@}
00591 
00592     /** \name Deprecated Functions
00593      **********************************************************************/
00594     ///@{
00595 
00596     /**
00597      * <b>DEPRECATED</b>.  Return the latitude, \e lat2, longitude, \e lon2,
00598      * and forward azimuth, \e azi2 (degrees) of the point 2 which is a
00599      * distance, \e s12 (in meters), from point 1.  Also return the reduced
00600      * length \e m12 (meters).  \e s12 can be signed.  If \e arcmode (default
00601      * false) is set to true, \e s12 is interpreted as the arc length \e a12
00602      * (in degrees) on the auxiliary sphere.  Returned value is the arc length
00603      * \e a12 (degrees) if \e arcmode is false, otherwise it is the distance \e
00604      * s12 (meters).
00605      **********************************************************************/
00606     Math::real Position(real s12, real& lat2, real& lon2,
00607                         real& azi2, real &m12, bool arcmode)
00608       const throw() {
00609       if (arcmode) {
00610         real s12x;
00611         ArcPosition(s12, lat2, lon2, azi2, s12x, m12);
00612         return s12x;
00613       } else
00614         return Position(s12, lat2, lon2, azi2, m12);
00615     }
00616 
00617     /**
00618      * <b>DEPRECATED</b>.  Return the scale of the geodesic line extending an
00619      * arc length \e a12 (degrees) from point 1 to point 2.  \e M12 (a number)
00620      * measures the convergence of initially parallel geodesics.  It is defined
00621      * by the following construction: starting at point 1 proceed at azimuth \e
00622      * azi1 + 90<sup>o</sup> a small distance \e dt; turn -90<sup>o</sup> and
00623      * proceed a distance \e s12 (\e not the arc length \e a12); the distance
00624      * to point 2 is given by \e M12 \e dt.  \e M21 is defined analogously.
00625      **********************************************************************/
00626     void Scale(real a12, real& M12, real& M21) const throw() {
00627       real lat2, lon2, azi2, s12;
00628       ArcPosition(a12, lat2, lon2, azi2, s12, M12, M21);
00629     }
00630     ///@}
00631 
00632   };
00633 
00634 } // namespace GeographicLib
